page.title: 06Butterflies in Blean woods
page.content: The woods are one of the few remaining sites in England where the HEATH FRITILLARY can be found. The colonies tend to move from area to area in the woods where the larvae feed on common cow-wheat MELAMPYRUM PRATENSE which grows on the edges of rides and in the coppiced areas. Most of the other common species including the brimstone are to be found in reasonable numbers, mainly along the open rides. Many entymologists visit the area as a great variety of insect life with some rare species can be studied. The wood provides a convenient stopping place for many invertebrates which may arrive from the continent, therefore totally unexpected species may be seen.
